div.p: From W. Baldwin Spencer to Charles Topp
E97/11925, unit 972, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center; font-variant: small-caps;

div.p:
To proof.
Baron von Mueller National Memorial Fund.
Charles A Topp Eq MA LLB etc

The committee formed at the close of the year 1896 for the purpose of establishing some fitting memorial in memory of the work of the late Baron von Mueller was unfortunately unable to take any practical steps and has been abandoned.

A new committee the members of which are enumerated in the enclosed circular
The General Committee, chaired by the Mayor of Melbourne, name, consisted of 56 men coming from the scientific, natural history, political and German communities of Australia, but mainly from Melbourne. The Executive Committee numbered thirteen: John Madden (Chief Justice), C. Blackett (Hon. Treasurer), W. Brahe, J. Bosisto, R. Ellery, C. Frost, A. Howitt, Prof. Kernot, A. Macdonald (previous Hon. Secretary), F. McCoy, J. Panton and W. Wiesbaden and W. Baldwin Spencer (Hon. Secs). has been formed & as Secretary of this, Mr A. C. Macdonald the secretary of the former Committee, has handed over to me various documents amongst which is a letter from yourself (no. 4764) of date 11 Oct. 1897
Letter not found. stating that "Any amount which may be granted for a public memorial to the late Baron von Mueller will be paid to the Memorial Committee."
public memorial … Committee has been underlined presumably by Topp.

I am instructed by the Executive Committee to communicate with you & to express the hope that the new
express the hope that the new has been underlined presumably by Topp.
Committee which has now been formed & the general object of which may be gathered from the enclosed circular
See Baron von Mueller National Memorial Fund, 15 November 1897. will receive the same support which was
receive the same support which was has been underlined presumably by Topp.
generously promised by the Government to the old & now disbanded committee. We are at the present moment soliciting support from the public and it would help us to a large extent if we could state definitely that the Committee would receive assistance from the Government of Victoria.
On 30 November 1897 Topp minuted: 'Forwarded to the Honourable the Premier for consideration. I think the present Executive Committee may be considered to have taken the place of the late Memorial Committee which is practically defunct and that any contribution made by the Government may be properly paid over to the new Executive Committee No doubt the Committee would be greatly aided especially in asking for some contribution from the Governments of other Colonies which have benefited by Baron Von Mueller's botanical researches if they could state that the Victorian Government intended to give a substantial donation to the Memorial Fund.'.
Topp's minute was referred Cabinet on 3 December and on 7 December it was decided that the Government 'will give £100 to the Memorial Committee'. R. Rogers, Secretary to the Premier, forwarded this decision to Topp the same day and Topp instructed that Spencer be informed.
